item.title: Geodesics via the Calculus of Variations
item.description:
When I explain geodesics to people, I usually use two intuitions:

  • Geodesics are the “straight lines” on curved surfaces, and;
  • Geodesics minimize distances between two points on curved surfaces.

The definition I used in this post is basically a more precise version of the first intuition, using the tool of parallel transport to define what is considered “straight” on a curved surface. However, for people who study Lagrangian mechanics, a definition based on the second intuition might be more straightforward, as the geodesic is the path that minimizes the action, if we define the action as the Euclidean distance between points.
